hints.content: Start by identifying the different components of the command string. You have three main parts to interpret: 'G', '()', and '(al)'. Each of these has a specific meaning.
Consider how you will traverse the string. A simple loop could be useful to go through each character and check for patterns that correspond to the components you need to interpret.
When you encounter 'G', you can directly add 'G' to your result. Think about how you will handle the parentheses when you see '()' or '(al)'.
For '()', remember that it translates to 'o'. You might want to create a temporary variable to build your result as you interpret each part of the string.
When you find '(al)', you should append 'al' to your result. Make sure to handle the parentheses correctly to avoid misinterpretation.
Think about how to differentiate between '()' and '(al)'. You can check the next characters after an opening parenthesis to determine which one it is.
Consider edge cases, such as consecutive '()' or the placement of 'G' at the beginning or end of the command. How will your logic handle these scenarios?
You might want to use a list to collect the interpreted parts of the command. At the end, you can join this list into a single string for the final output.
As you build your result, think about the order of operations. Ensure that you are appending to your result in the same order that you encounter the components in the string.
Finally, ensure that your solution handles the maximum constraint of the command length. Test your implementation with various combinations of 'G', '()', and '(al)' to validate its correctness.

questionNotes: The command consists of 'G', '()', and/or '(al)' in any order.
Return the concatenated interpretation of the command.
Ensure to handle edge cases with different combinations of components.
